PROGRAM AND LOAN SUMMARY 

Islamic Republic of Pakistan  

Support for the Punjab Resource Management Program (PRMP, the 
Program),  comprising  (i)  a  program  cluster  concept  for  public 
resource  management  reforms  in  Punjab,  (ii)  a  program  loan  for 
subprogram  1  of  the  Program,  and  (iii)  a  technical  assistance  (TA) 
loan for supporting public resource management reforms in Punjab. 
 
 
Despite  many  initiatives  aimed  at  developing  Pakistan’s  economic 
and social sectors, the country’s level of development remains below 
its  potential  and  social  indicators  are  lagging.  The  incidence  of 
poverty today is higher than a decade ago. Among the root causes for 
the  poor  development  performance  is  a  crisis  of  governance  at  all 
levels  of  government.  There  is  ample  evidence  that  improvement  in 
public  sector  governance  and 
resource  management  yields 
considerable development gains. 
 
Pakistan has initiated substantial governance reforms over the past 3 
years.  Devolution  of  powers  to  local  governments  has  been  at  the 
center of these reforms. This has significantly impacted on provincial 
responsibilities  at  all  stages  of  public  service  delivery.  Whereas 
primary responsibility for service delivery in many areas now lies with 
local  governments,  provincial  governments  have  to  adjust  to  a  new 
role  with  a  focus  on  policy  setting,  financing,  monitoring,  and 
oversight,  and  have  to  realign  their  systems,  procedures,  and 
governance  structures  accordingly.  The  elections  in  October  2002 
have broadened the mandate to further the reform agenda. Reforms 
in  Punjab,  the  country’s  largest  province  with  more  than  half  of  the 
country’s population and economic activity, are therefore expected to 
have a far-reaching impact on the country and its people as a whole.  
 
The  goal  of  the  Program  is  to  achieve  targeted  improvements  in 
socioeconomic  indicators  in  Punjab,  as  outlined  in  the  federal 
Government's  Poverty  Reduction  Strategy  Paper  (PRSP),  through 
efficient  and  sustainable  delivery  of  public  services 
that  are 
responsive  to  the  dynamic  needs  of  Punjab’s  society.  The  Program 
will  complement  and  integrate  at  the  provincial  level  with  various 
other  governance-related  initiatives  anchored  in  the  PRSP,  including 
those  for  fiscal  devolution,  decentralized  social  service  delivery, 
financial reporting and auditing, and gender reform. 
 
The  purpose  and  policy  objectives  of  the  Program  are  to  assist  the 
government  of  Punjab  through  reforms  in  governance  structures, 
systems,  and  processes  to  (i)  strengthen  its  provincial  finances,  (ii) 
realign  provincial  institutions  for  pro-poor  service  delivery,  and  (iii) 
create  opportunities  for  growth  and  income  generation  in  the  private 
sector.

THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT1 

 
2. 
Economic  Recovery  Gaining  Strength.  Pakistan  has  coped  well  with  the  difficult 
internal and external challenges it has been facing over recent years. The Government was able 
to  stabilize  the  fragile  economic  situation  it  was  facing  at  the  end  of  the  1990s,  despite  the 
global  economic  slowdown  as  well  as  the  uncertainties  following  the  terrorist  attacks  in  the 
United States (US) on 11 September 2001 and the war in Iraq in early 2003. The turnaround of 
the monetary indicators has been particularly impressive: foreign exchange reserves increased 
from less than $1 billion in early 2000 to more than $11 billion in mid-2003, aided largely by a 
shift in remittances from overseas Pakistanis through formal channels, rescheduling of external 
debt  payments,  and  increased  official  transfers;  interest  rates  have  been  brought  down 
significantly for both public and private sector debt; inflation has been kept under control at 3–
4%; and the Pakistan rupee has been gaining strength and has stabilized against the US dollar. 
Recognizing  these  positive  developments,  international  credit  agencies  have  upgraded  their 
financial risk ratings for Pakistan.2  
 
3. 
Need  to  Sustain  Growth.  Following  the  achievements  on  the  monetary  front,  recent 
indications  show  a  pickup  in  real  sector  growth  as  well.  The  gross  domestic  product  (GDP) 
growth  rate  in  fiscal  year  (FY)  2003  is  estimated  at  5.1%,  after  3.4%  in  FY2002  and  2.2%  in 
FY2001.  This  recent  upswing  was  aided  by  some  benign  external  developments,  including 
favorable  weather  conditions  that  supported  the  agriculture  sector,  improved  access  to 
developed  markets  for  Pakistan’s  goods  as  a  result  of  Pakistan’s  support  for  the  US-led 
antiterrorism  coalition,  as  well  as  defense-related  expenditures.  Yet  the  foundations  for 
domestic and foreign investment need to be strengthened to broaden the growth base beyond 
external  events  and  assistance,  and  sustain  the  higher  levels  that  are  required  for  poverty 
reduction.  Meeting  the  growth  target  for  FY2004,  which  is  set  at  5.3%,  will  require  increased 
development spending and measures to improve investment and competitiveness, alongside a 
monetary policy that contains expansion of liquidity (resulting from continued foreign exchange 
inflows), keeps inflation under control, and preserves financial stability.

Board  of  Revenue  for  strengthening  tax  collection  is  an  important  element  in  Pakistan’s  fiscal

Key  Functions  of  Provincial  Government.  Pakistan’s  constitution  accords  a  key 
responsibility  in  the  delivery  of  public  services  to  its  provinces,  including  social  and  physical 
infrastructure  provision  and  associated  services.  This  includes  important  areas  such  as 
agriculture,  natural  resources  and  environmental  management  (including  irrigation,  water  and 
mineral  resources),  social  services  (including  education,  health,  social  welfare),  physical 
infrastructure  (including  roads,  municipal  services,  water  supply  and  sanitation),  economic 
services  for  private  sector  development  (including  sector  regulation,  support  services,  labor 
exchanges),  as  well  as  asset  protection  and  public  order  (including  historical  monuments, 
police,  law  and  order).  Some  functions  of  the  provinces  may  also  be  taken  up  by  the  federal 
Government  and  require  adequate  coordination.  Moreover,  important  service  functions  are 
delegated further to local governments at district, tehsil, and union levels.  
 
12. 
Impact of Decentralization With the advent of the Local Government Ordinance 2001, 
primary  responsibility  for  the  bulk  of  service  delivery  (including  elementary  education,  curative 
health, rural development, farm-to-market roads, and municipal services) was delegated further 
to local governments. By implication, this has redefined and fundamentally impacted provincial 
responsibilities at all stages of public service delivery, including planning, financing, execution, 
and  monitoring.  Provincial  governments  have  a  key  role  to  (i) ensure  that  stable,  predictable, 
and sufficient fiscal resources are made available for service delivery; (ii) devise instruments for 
intergovernmental  financing  to  encourage  local  government  implementation  of  province-wide 
policy  commitments  on  poverty;  (iii) establish  the  policies,  standards,  and  procedures  for 
integrated  and  sector-specific  service  delivery  (including  human  resources  policies),  while 
ensuring accountability and ensuring that local authorities act within the provisions of new legal 
and 
institutional  arrangements;  and  (iv)  enable  effective  private  sector-led  economic 
development.  This  will  require  an  important  adjustment  of  key  provincial  institutions  and 
governance arrangements.

29. 
Skewed and Rigid Expenditure Structure Dominated by High Establishment Costs. 
On  the  expenditure  side,  flexibility  for  much-needed  structural  shifts  is  limited  by  high 
establishment costs, comprising salaries and pension payments, which account for more than 
half of total spending. This is a result of overextended, partly uneconomic, public infrastructure 
networks and staff-heavy but ineffective social service networks that are fiscally unsustainable. 
In  addition,  a  considerable  portion,  about  14%  of  expenditures,  is  allocated  for  servicing 
provincial  debt,  primarily  cash  development  loans  (CDLs)  from  the  federal Government, which 
carry high interest. The rigid structure has resulted in persistent and worsening underspending 
on critical nonsalary inputs, including O&M of key facilities and pro-poor services. To rectify this 
situation, the provincial government has taken steps to limit further expansion of establishment 
costs,  reduce  subsidies,  and  develop  a  debt  management  strategy  with  a  view  to  generate 
additional fiscal space through reduction of interest payments. Implementation of this strategy is 
aided through a benign interest environment at present. 
 
30. 
Buildup  of  High  Liabilities.  Punjab’s  debt  has  increased  considerably  over  the  past 
decade,  with  an  accumulated  debt  stock  of  PRs121.2  billion  at  the  end  of  FY2002.  A  large 
portion of this, PRs86.9 billion, was financed through expensive CDLs. Some of the loans were 
obtained  at  rates  above  17%.  Refinancing  of  liabilities  thus  offers  a  particular  opportunity  to 
achieve greater fiscal space in the near term.  
 
31.  With  the  discontinuation  of  CDLs  in  1998,  and  curtailment  of  overdraft  arrangements 
with the State Bank of Pakistan (SBP), the overall budget deficits more recently could only be 
financed  by  building  up  arrears  and  utilizing  off-budget  funds  held  by  the  Government  in  a 
fiduciary  capacity,  including  the  General  Provident  Fund  of  civil  service  employees,  which  has 
accumulated liabilities of about PRs17 billion. There is also a considerable amount of unfunded 
and  contingent  liabilities  that  are  not  adequately  provided  for,  including  civil service pensions 
and liabilities of autonomous bodies and PSOs. Pension liabilities in particular are growing at a 
rapid pace and could seriously disrupt provincial finances in a decade or so if no measures are 
taken now. They increased from PRs1.7 billion in FY1991 to about PRs10.8 billion in FY2003. In 
addition, the provincial government has extended a number of loans and guarantees to PSOs 
that have  become  nonperforming.  Outstanding  nonperforming  loans  by  the  province  to  PSOs 
are estimated at more than PRs35 billion, with an additional PRs6 billion of guarantees to PSOs 
for  borrowing  transactions  that  are  not  sustainable.  To  ensure  the  medium-  and  long-term 
sustainability of provincial finances, there is an urgent need to devise strategies to deal with the 
unfunded pension liabilities and to rectify the financial positions of the PSOs by writing off debt 
that  is  not  recoverable.  The  Government  has  initiated  steps  to  address  this  unsustainable 
situation and created a working group to look into these issues, in particular financing of pension 
liabilities, and these steps need to be taken further.

 Decentralization  of  Authority.  The  ambitious  reforms  initiated in 2000 to restructure 
administrative,  functional,  financial,  and  fiscal  relations  between  different  levels  of  government 
aim  to  transfer  power  to  lower  government  formations  through  devolution  of  authority  and 
granting  of  autonomy.  Under  the  new  system,  the  role  of  the  provincial  governments  will  be 
transformed  from  a  direct  provider  of  some  basic  social  and  community  services  to  financing, 
regulation,  and  supervision  of  local  governments  as  primary  delivery  agents.  The  shifting  of 
resources and  authority  to  lower  levels  of  government  is  expected  to  make  the  Government 
responsive  to  local  needs  and  priorities.  The  decentralization  reforms  thus  present  a  unique 
opportunity  to  improve  delivery  of  services  within  the  framework  of  effective,  efficient, 
transparent, accountable, and participatory governance structures. Yet the overriding challenge 
will  be  to  manage  the  transformation  to  the  new  system.  This  will  require  a  shift  in  attitudes, 
processes,  and  institutional  arrangements,  including  establishment of a few new institutions at 
the provincial level (such as the local government commission and PFC). Unless new processes 
can  be  institutionalized  over  the  next  few  years,  intended  benefits  may  not  be  realized  and 
reforms are at risk of being rolled back. Managing decentralization will thus require both strong 
political  commitment  to  redesign  existing  structures  and  processes,  and  considerable  training 
and skills development at various levels of government. 
 
34. 
Participatory  Approaches  for  Policy Formulation and Investment Planning.  A key 
aspect  in  managing  decentralization  at  the  provincial  level  and  in  improving  public  service 
delivery is to establish an effective system that allows the linking of priorities formulated through 
participatory  approaches  within  an  overall  planning  and  investment  framework  that  takes 
account  of  resource  availabilities. 
Improved  institutional  arrangements  for  participatory 
mechanisms  should  enable  local  communities  to  better  articulate  and  realize  their  choices  by 
designing investment programs and by taking on expenditure commitments based on their own 
needs and local priorities. This will require a reorientation of the centralized and control-oriented 
systems  and  procedures  established  in  the  past  in  provincial  agencies,  and  a  shift  of  key 
provincial  agencies  toward  more  emphasis  on  policy  formulation  and  oversight  rather  than 
project programming and execution. The successful implementation of participatory approaches 
will require considerable capacity building at both provincial and local levels of government and 
an  effective  coordination  mechanism.  The  provincial  Government  took  a  first  step  in 
institutionalizing  this  process  through  the  creation  of  the  Punjab  Development  Forum  (PDF), 
which  held  its  first  meeting  in  September  2003,  and  which  is  to  become  a  regular  feature  of 
stakeholder  consultation  prior  to  annual  budget  formulation.  A  number  of  important  policy 
announcements were made publicly at the PDF, and next year’s PDF is expected to scrutinize 
progress in implementation and provide a platform for structured discussion.

Accountability  and  Transparency  in  Financial  Management.  Lack  of  accountability 
and  transparency  in  financial  management  and  absence  of  transparent  rules  provide  rent-
seeking  opportunities  for  public  officials  at  the  expense  of  society.  Corruption  is  widely 
perceived  by  the  general  public  to  be  a  major  problem.  Internal  controls  and  accountability 
systems have weakened over time and are characterized by inadequate accounting practices. 
Poorly  functioning  financial  reporting  and  management  systems  and  procedures  have 
compromised the reliability of provincial accounts and the quality of financial management. The 
auditing function has not lived up to its promise because the accounts were not presented on a 
timely  basis  and  the  public  accounts  committee  (PAC)  were  either  not  in  place  or  did  not 
function  regularly  to  review  the  audit  reports  promptly,  thereby  constraining  the  usefulness  of 
the  audit  system.  In  view  of  the  delays  with  which  audit  reports  have  either  been  produced  or 
reviewed,  the  PAC  has  not  been  particularly  effective  in  highlighting  and  correcting  poor 
compliance with financial policies, systems, and procedures.  
 
37. 
Shift in Incentive Structures.  A  key  element  to  improve  public  service  delivery  is  to 
achieve  a  shift  in  incentive  structures  for  performance.  While  a  change  in  government 
procedures  and  support  systems,  including  performance-based human resources systems, is 
an  important  factor,  lasting  improvements  may  only  be  achieved  through  private  sector 
participation  and  the  competition  for  excellence  this  brings.  Punjab  is  in  a  relatively  fortunate 
position compared to other provinces as it has both a better educated civil service as well as a 
dynamic private sector.  
 
38. 
Reform Momentum and Political Support. Punjab is in a relatively good position vis-à-
vis  other  provinces  to  carry  out  and  benefit  from  public  sector  reforms.  The  province  has  a 
diversified  economy  with  good  growth  and  tax  potential,  an  entrepreneurial  business 
community,  and  probably  better  capacity  in  the  civil  service.  Unlike  the  other  provinces,  the 
elections  in  October  2002  resulted  in  a  clear  majority  and  mandate  for  the  provincial 
government to proceed with the reform program initiated under the previous administration. The 
federal  Government  is  closely  associated  with  the  previous  administration  that  initiated  these 
reforms  and  with  further  advancing  the  reform  agenda.  In  addition,  the  devolution  program  in 
particular  enjoys  the  strong  support  of  Pakistan’s  president,  and  by  implication  this  has 
considerable impact on provincial resource management. The continued deterioration of public 
services  has  further  exacerbated  the  need  for  structural  reforms.  All  this  presents  a  timely 
opportunity for a holistic rather than piecemeal approach to create an effective and accountable 
civil service administration and public service delivery.

Human  Resources  Management  and  Accountability.  The  weak  performance  of 
Punjab’s  public  institutions  is  a  reflection  of  inadequate  human  resources  policy  and 
management,  and  lack  of  accountability.  The  skills  base  in  many  instances  is  unsuited  to

made with good intentions to prevent staff from becoming too entrenched in their positions and

Promotion and guidelines are not very clear, and rising through the ranks is still based more on 
seniority  than  on  performance,  in  the  absence  of  clear  accountability  rules  and  performance 
monitoring systems. Together with a pay structure that has not kept pace with market trends, in 
particular for positions of responsibility, it has become increasingly difficult to attract and retain 
suitable  talent  for  key  institutions.  However,  Punjab  has  a  large  human  resources  pool  to  tap, 
and improvement in human resources development, as well as outsourcing of selected services 
and  institutions  on  a  contractual  basis  to  the  private  sector  with  clearly  defined  performance 
criteria, could yield considerable efficiency gains.

Lessons Learned 

C. 
 
43. 
Lessons can be drawn from previous experience in policy-based adjustment lending by 
ADB and other funding agencies in Pakistan,21 as well as from ADB support for governance and 
resource  management  programs  elsewhere.  There  has  been  considerable  experience  with 
program  lending  in  Pakistan  recently,  including  eight  program  or  sector  development  program 
loans approved by ADB since 1999. Generally, implementation of these loans so far has been 
progressing satisfactorily. Key lessons learned include the importance of strong ownership and 
a  committed  executing  agency  (EA)  to  drive  implementation,  need  for  broad-based  political 
support  and  consultation  in  particular  for  cross-sector  reforms,  focused  design  and  realistic 
implementation time frames, and strong implementation support, including TA loans.  
 
44.  While  there  is  considerable  familiarity  at  the  federal  level  with  adjustment  lending,  the 
proposed Program is the first program-lending intervention by ADB at the provincial level. Some 
experience with provincial adjustment lending has been gained by the World Bank in Sindh and 
North-West  Frontier  Province.  A  key  lesson  there  is  the  importance  of  taking  into  account 
provincial considerations and capacities, which can be quite different from those at the federal 
level.  ADB  has  gained  some  experience  with  resource  management  programs  at  the 
subnational  level  elsewhere,  in  particular  in  India,  which  highlight  the  importance  of  adequate 
stakeholder  consultation  during  program  formulation  and  implementation,  as  well  as  the  need 
for a realistic and medium-term time frame, given the complexities inherent in such programs. 
Cluster programs have been introduced following the last review of lending program policies in 
1999 to allow for more realistic and better sequenced program time frames, but so far no cluster 
has reached its completion date. In addition, ADB supported  the Social Action Program (Sector 
Project)  in  Pakistan  during  the  early  and  mid-1990s,  which  aimed  to  improve  social  indicators 
through  boosting  social  sector  spending.  Much  of  this  spending,  which  was  incremental  in 
nature, has proven to be unsustainable  in the absence both of related governance reforms and 
of measures to generate fiscal space needed to finance sustainable incremental spending.

54. 
Component  1  seeks  to  provide  fiscal  space  for  sustainable  investments  in  pro-poor

(ii) rationalizing  provincial  expenditures;  and  (iii) improving  effectiveness,  predictability,  and 
accountability in financial management. The key policy result under this component would be a 
stronger  revenue  base  to  finance  a  switch  in  expenditures  toward  high-priority social sector 
interventions, with enhanced accountability and control over utilization of funds. The attainment 
of this objective on a sustainable basis will have to be supplemented by administrative reforms, 
which  will  require  the  strong  commitment  of  the  government.  Major  shifts  in  revenues  and 
expenditures as envisaged are presented in the medium term fiscal framework in Appendix 6.

107.  To enhance capacity for implementation and sustainability of the PRMP reform agenda,

116.  The  realization  of  program  benefits  and  impacts  will  depend  on  a  number  of 
assumptions that are subject to a variety of risks. Mitigating measures have been integrated in 
the  program  design  as  appropriate,  taking  account  of  past  experiences  in  program  lending  in

117.  Political  and  Continuity  Risks.  There  have  been  many  instances  in  Pakistan  where 
program agreements faced considerable implementation delays or were not fully implemented 
due  to  political  pressures,  often  linked  to  a  change  in  government  (which  have  occurred 
frequently over the past decade). Opposition to reform has generally been encountered at both 
the political and bureaucratic levels, in particular when privatization or downsizing measures or 
reduction  of  subsidies  have  been  involved.  Other  than  for  pure  political  motives,  much  of  the 
opposition  stems  from  misinformation  and  lack  of  clear  communication  about  program 
implications to key stakeholders.

development  objectives  has  been  exacerbated  by  the  lack  of  public  consultation,  and  the 
absence of a dialogue between the executive and elected representatives as well as elements of 
civil  society.  The  problem  is  exacerbated  by  the  lack  of  a  long-term  development  strategy  or 
vision for the province, which would provide the framework within which all development-related 
activities would occur. Budget allocations thus continue to be made incrementally, rather than in 
the  wider  frame  of  medium-term  priorities  and  poverty  goals  and  a  robustly  determined 
estimation  of  corresponding  resource  availability.  The  bulk  of  budgetary  expenditures  (about 
75% of the total) are classified as permanent recurrent expenditures, which are rarely reviewed 
to establish consistency with the Punjab government's development priorities or policies.  
 
22. 
Identification  and  Approval  of  Development  Schemes.  The  Planning  and 
Development Department (P&DD), government of Punjab, issues a directive to all departments 
at  the  end  of  the  second  quarter  of  the  fiscal  year,  asking  them  to  recommend  development 
schemes  for  inclusion  in  the  annual  development  program  (ADP).  P&DD  also  issues  a  set  of 
guidelines according to which the recommendations are to be made, including the proviso that 
schemes  be  listed  in  order  of  priority  within  sectors  and  subsectors,  project  components  to  be 
funded  through  foreign  aid  be  listed  separately  in  rupee  terms,  and  ongoing  schemes  at 
advanced  stages  of  development  be  adequately  funded.  The  departments  are  also  advised  to 
finalize their programs after thorough in-house discussions and give special attention to projects 
that  are  deemed  to  be  significant  according  to  the  development  priorities  of  the  province  as  a 
whole. Each department than sends estimates of development expenditure over the next fiscal 
year to P&DD in the form of draft demands for funds. 
 
23. 
As the third quarter of the fiscal year closes, the draft demands are scrutinized by P&DD. 
Prior  to  1998,  the  bulk  of  development  schemes  at  the  provincial  level  were  funded  by  the 
federal Government through cash development loans (CDLs), and the federal Government thus 
discussed  most  draft  demands  from  the  provinces  in  the  Priorities  Committee,  chaired  by  the 
Ministry of Finance and then in the Annual Plan Coordination Committee (APCC) of the Planning

the Priorities Committee were forwarded to the National Economic Council chaired by the Prime

24. 
The  federal  Government  discontinued  the  facility  of  providing  CDLs  to  provincial 
governments  in  1998.  Nevertheless,  the  Planning  Commission  still  accords  approval  to  all 
schemes of over  PRs200 million. In addition, the APCC is still convened to approve a Federal 
Public Sector Development Program (PSDP), a significant proportion of which is implemented in 
the provinces. In Punjab, all development schemes of over PRs20 million are approved by the 
Provincial Development Working Party (PDWP) chaired by P&DD, although these are now being 
implemented at the district level, while schemes of less than PRs20 million are approved at the 
district level by district development committees. Similarly, all schemes that have a component 
of  foreign  funding  are  approved  by  the  PDWP.  Thus  in  spite  of  devolution  of  implementation 
responsibilities, approval processes have not been entirely devolved. The process as described 
above has the following flaws.  
 
25. 
Dichotomy Between Approval and Allocation. Once approved, however, development 
schemes are not necessarily funded in the ADP. Also, the ADP does not necessarily include only 
approved schemes, but unapproved ones as well. There is in fact no coherent linkage between 
approval  and  allocation  of  funds.  While  a  certain  degree  of  overprogramming  is  advisable  to 
ensure  that  funds  are  not  left  unused,  the  system  of  according  approval  to  projects  without 
ensuring availability of funds renders the planning process meaningless. Similarly the inclusion 
of unapproved schemes in the ADP, a practice that the government of Punjab has now decided 
to  discontinue,  negated  the  whole  planning  exercise  further.  Given  that  the  bulk  of  the  ADP 
resources are taken up by funding of ongoing schemes,6 most of which are subject to cost and 
time overruns, the effort expended in preparation of new schemes and their approval tends to be 
wasted.  
 
26. 
Dichotomy  Between  Actual  and  Required  Allocation.  The  absence  of  a  linkage 
between  approval  and  allocation  manifests  itself  particularly  in  the  discrepancy  in  actual  and 
required allocations for projects in the ADP. Annual required allocations as specified in the PC-
1s  of  projects  are  hardly  ever  accommodated  in  the  ADP,  as  a  result  of  which  schemes  are 
rarely completed on time and within the original cost estimates. A cursory analysis of amounts 
allocated to new schemes in the ADP for FY2003 reveals that only 55% of required amounts, as 
specified in the respective PC-1s, were actually allocated to these schemes.7  
 
27.  Moreover, the linkages between initial and recurrent costs of new projects have not been 
established through well-defined procedures. While the PC-1s give estimates of future recurrent 
costs,  there  is  no  procedure  for  ensuring  that  these  are  reflected  in  subsequent  recurrent 
expenditures  funded  by  the  Finance  Department.  There  is  thus  a  disconnect  between 
development and recurrent budgets, with obvious consequences in the form of mismatches. This 
fundamental  disconnect  has  also  led  to  the  existence  of  “throw  forward”  in  the  ADP,  as  new 
schemes are added without consideration of the funding requirements of existing ones. The size

29. 
Incremental Demands. The problem of incremental budgeting tends to occur in the case 
of  development  budgets  also.  P&DD’s  instructions  to  departments  specify  that  the  increase  in 
draft demands have to be contained to a certain percentage increase over last year’s allocations 
(the directive for FY2004 specifies this as 20%). There is a tendency for departments to prepare 
draft demands according to this “formula”, i.e., adding to last year’s allocations to the extent of 
the  ceiling  specified  without  consideration  of  whether  this  level  of  expenditure  is  what  is  really 
required or whether it can be accommodated. This strategy has paybacks for the departments, 
however,  in  that  it  is  a  way  of  securing  access  to  limited  resources  given  that  P&DD  tries  to 
accommodate  the  maximum  number  of  schemes  in  the  ADP  in  any  given  year,  even  if  this 
means allocating resources far below required amounts for each scheme. The departments thus 
use their draft demands to stake a claim on future resource allocations, without consideration of 
the status of ongoing programs, which remain underfunded and incomplete.

Based on an in-depth examination of the quantitative  and qualitative analyses of poverty

The PPRSP identifies governance reform, strengthening of planning capability, improvement of 
service delivery and fiscal and financial reform, and creation of an investor-friendly environment 
as key issues for effective poverty reduction in Punjab, in addition to mainstreaming of gender 
and  environment  issues  and  income  and  employment  generation.  Each  of  these  key  areas  of 
intervention  have  been  covered  in  the  proposed  Punjab  Resource  Management  Program 
(PRMP).  The  PRMP  thus  strongly  complements  the  PPRSP  and  will  provide  support  for  the 
implementation of PPRSP recommendations. 
 
2. 
Earlier,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  Poverty  Assessment  for  Pakistan  had 
identified  governance  as  the  key  cause  of  poverty  in  Pakistan,  which  not  only  resulted  in  poor 
public  service  delivery  and  enhanced  vulnerability,  but  is  the  prime  cause  of  low  business 
confidence,  which  in  turn  translates  into  lower  investment  levels  and  growth.  The  Poverty 
Assessment  was  the  main  input  for  the  Country  Strategy  and  Program  (CSP)  (2002–2006), 
which  delineates  ADB’s  medium-term  development  strategy  for  Pakistan,  which  has  been 
framed  in  the  context  of  the  national  PRSP  and  the  ongoing  efforts  to  create  a  feasible 
monitoring  framework  linked  to  the  budget  and  the  International  Monetary  Fund's  Poverty

2. 

Poverty Analysis: Poverty and Public Resource Management in Punjab 

 
3. 
Insufficient  provision  and  poor  quality  of  public  services  have  contributed  to  the 
worsening poverty in the province. Inadequate public services in health and education combined 
with  inadequate  maintenance  of  roads,  irrigation  systems,  water  supply  schemes,  and  other 
infrastructure  have  contributed  directly  to  low  economic  growth,  poor  social  indicators,  and  the 
consequent  inability  to  reduce  poverty.  Poor service  delivery  is  tied  to  declining  public  sector 
expenditures  in  the  vicious  circle  of  provincial  finances  and  to  poor  incentives  for  service 
delivery. 
 
4. 
Low revenues and high debt service and establishment costs cause the fiscal squeeze. 
Almost 80% of the provincial current expenditures are committed to pensions, interest payments, 
subsidies,  and  the  wage  bill,  as  well  as  grants  to  local  governments.  The  annual  development 
program  has  been  overloaded  with  ongoing  projects  that  entail  large  “throw  forward”  of 
expenditure  liabilities.  The  input  focus  of  the  budget  process  and  the  inability  to  prioritize  or 
review  the  bulk  of  the  expenditure  items  under  the  incremental  budgeting  process,  combined 
with  the  tendency  to  enforce  damaging  short-term  expenditure  controls  to  address  the  fiscal 
squeeze, have seriously reduced the effectiveness of public expenditures in Punjab. Reforms in 
underlying systems and processes to manage public resources are therefore crucial to reverse 
the increased incidence of poverty in Punjab.

The Context 

Key Gender Issues in the Public Sector 

 
A. 
 
1. 
Gender inequality in access to services and justice is evident from gender indicators of 
Pakistan.  This  is  true  for  Punjab  as  well.  Violation  of  women’s  rights  and  violence  against 
women  remains  an  everyday  experience  of  women  across  the  class,  region,  and  rural-urban 
divides. Women bear a disproportionately high share of the burden of poverty within the family 
and  society.  Moreover,  the  poorer  the  family,  the  higher  is  the  likelihood  of  significant 
dependence  on  female  labor.  The  patriarchal  bias  in  state  institutions  translates  into 
underinvestment in their social and economic entitlements and reinforces the higher incidence of 
poverty  and  powerlessness  among  women.  Representation  of  women  in  political  and 
administrative  setups  of  government  has  been  a  successful  strategy  to  promote  the  gender 
equality agenda in many countries. In Pakistan, there are substantial gender disparities in public 
sector employment including the civil service. Women are concentrated in the lower spectra of 
the job hierarchy. Political representation of women is ensured through reserved seats but their 
ability to negotiate and promote the gender equality agenda are limited by patriarchal structures. 
 
B. 
 
2. 
Implementation  of  National  Commitments  on  Gender.  In  addition  to  international 
commitments  and  obligations,  the  Government  has  made  a  number  of  policy  commitments  on 
gender  equality  under  National  Plan  of  Action  (NPA)  in  1998  and  National  Policy  on 
Development  and  Empowerment  of  Women  in  2002,  by  allocating  a  33%  reserved  quota  for 
women  in  local  government  and  17%  representation  for  women  in  national  and  provincial 
assemblies.  However,  these  commitments  have  not  been  matched  by  political,  administrative, 
and financial support.  
 
3. 
Public  Expenditure  on  Promoting  Gender  Equality.  There  has  been  an  overall 
decrease in the capital budget of Punjab from 16.3% in 1991/92 to 7.9% in 2001/02. As a result, 
investment  in  targeted  gender  and  development  programs  remains  low.  In  addition  to  social 
sector departments, mainly health and education, the Women Development Department (WDD) 
is  responsive  to  gender  inequality  issues.  However,  the  allocation  for  women’s  development 
(part  of  social  welfare,  as  a  sector)  remained  below  1%  of  the  total  expenditure.  Within  the 
department's  own  domain,  the  allocations  to  recurrent  budget  have  consumed  most  of  the 
resources.  The  current  expenditure  of  the  WDD  in  the  last  10  years  has  hovered  between 
PRs230  million  and  PRs300  million;  however,  the  devolution  of  functions  to  the  district 
governments  have  resulted  in  a  drop  of  around  50%  in  this  respect.  The  allocations  for 
development budgets have been extremely low in the last 10 years, averaging a mere PRs3.0 
million. There is a need to develop gender-sensitive budgetary framework for the  provincial and 
district governments to increase investment in promoting gender equality.  
 
4. 
Gender  Policy  Formulation  and  Matching  Institutional  Arrangements. The current 
state  of  policy  formulation  and  program  execution  in  line  departments  of  the  provincial 
government show a clear lack of gender commitments and meaningful effort to address gender 
concerns in the context of a rights-based approach. The rules of business, job descriptions, and 
staff capacity of most of the departments are not aligned to promote the gender equality agenda. 
Moreover,  the  task  of  ensuring  gender  mainstreaming  across  provincial  departments  is  the 
mandate of WDD, which does not have the proper institutional framework, staff, or capacity to 
deliver on this mandate. The subject of women’s development is dealt with by a deputy director 
with minimal staff. There is no dedicated setup at the provincial secretariat and district levels.
